Napa Forecasts 1 Introduction In this report we document demand forecasting efforts undertaken for Lake Berryessa Resort Improvement District (LBRID) and Napa Berryessa Resort Improvement District (NBRID), special districts of Napa County in northern California. We begin with a brief overview of the data cleaning process.

2 Forecasting Methodology To forecast aggregate usage, we independently derive forecasts for the number of accounts and per-account usage. Utilizing agency-level aggregated monthly data, we regress the number of accounts on time for each agency/class combination with the following model: accountst, d, s = β0 + β1date + ϵt, d, s where accountst, d is the number of accounts for service s (water or sewer), in division d in time t, β0 is the intercept, and ϵt, d is an error term. In this model, β1 represents the time trend for accounts. We simulataneously forecasted per-account usage according to the following econometric specification: ut, d, s = β0 + β1date + β2precipt + β3ETt + Drought2015 + ϵt, d, s where ut, d, s is per-account usage for service s in time t for division d. We normalize for weather by including precipitation (precipt) and ET (ETt) and Drought2015 is an indicator variable for observations within the mandatory drought restriction time period to control for artificial deviations in demand. Per-account usage has been declining statewide in recent years because of behavioral changes stemming from water shortage concerns as well as the implementation of increasingly efficient appliances. Although this trend is likely to continue, there is a limit for how much water consumption can reduce because of the vital role water plays in daily life. Because of this, we impose a lower bound on per-account consumption reduction in our model. Currently, the lower bound is defined as 70% of the average per-account usage level for the specified month. The forecasts in this report utilize median ET and precipitation values by month from the CIMIS data dating back to 2006. In the accompanying .csv files, wet and dry year forecasts are included. A wet year is defined as year in which ET in all months is equivalent to the 25th percentile of ET values for that specific month, while precipitation values are the 75th percentile of precipitation values for that month. Alternatively, a dry year is defined in a similar fashion, except with the percentile values for ET and precipitation switched.

3 LBRID 3.1 Introduction The districts bill customers on an overlapping bi-monthly schedule. LBRID bills their customers in even-numbered months, utilizing a two-tiered rate structure. The first 8,000 gallons of water bi-monthly (or 4,000 gallons monthly) are included in the fixed bi-monthly charge. All usage above 8,000 gallons is charged at $3.85 per 1,000 gallons. For the purpose of this study, RDN defined the District’s rates as a two-tiered increasing block rate strucutre wherein customers pay $0 for the first 8,000 gallons of water (Tier 1) and $3.85 per 1,000 gallons (Tier 2) thereafter. LBRID rates were last increased 1 July, 2013. Most LBRID customers also have a sewer connection. A similar two-tiered rate structure is also implemented for LBRID sewer accounts - customers are allocated 4,000 gallons with their fixed charge and pay $5.50 per 1,000 gallons over this amount, capped at 6,000 gallons per month (which is the estimate of per-account winter residential waste flows). It follows that the maximum variable charge for a sewer customer would be $11.00 (4,000 gallons at $0.00 and 2,000 gallons at $5.50). RDN backed out sewer consumption from metered use by assuming that sewer consumption is equal to metered water consumption if metered water consumption is less than or equal to 12,000 gallons for the bi-monthly meter read and 12,000 gallons if metered water consumption is above 12,000 gallons for a given two-month period. 3.2 Historical Data 3.2.1 Total Usage Table 3.1: Historical Consumption 4 NBRID 4.1 Introduction NBRID employs a similar two-tiered rate structure for water and sewer customers, albeit it with different allocation levels and nominal rates. NBRID customers pay no variable charge for their first 2,000 gallons bi-monthly (or 1,000 gallons monthly), and are charged $4.00 per 1,000 gallons above this usage level. With respect to sewer rates, NBRID also caps sewer usage at 6,000 gallons per month. However, NBRID allocates only 1,000 gallons to the no-charge Tier 1 usage.
